monumentInformation.title: Who Built It
details: The Maya civilization built Chichén Itza, with its major structures constructed between the 9th and 12th centuries CE.
The city was later influenced by the Toltec culture, evident in the architectural style of the site.

monumentInformation.title: Where It Is Located
details: Chichen Itza is located in the Yucatán Peninsula, Mexico, about 120 kilometers east of Merida.
The site covers an area of approximately 10 square kilometers and is situated near the ancient cenotes (natural wells).

monumentInformation.title: When It Was Built
details: Chichen Itza was established around the 6th century CE and reached its peak between the 9th and 12th centuries CE.
Key structures, like the Temple of Kukulcan (El Castillo), were built during this peak period.

monumentInformation.title: Who Is It Protected By
details: Chichen Itza was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1988 due to its cultural and historical significance.
It is protected and maintained by the National Institute of Anthropology and History (INAH) of Mexico.

monumentInformation.title: Why It Was Built
details: Chichen Itza served as a major political, religious, and economic center for the Maya civilization.
The site was built to honor Mayan deities, particularly Kukulcán (the feathered serpent god), and features structures for astronomical observations, rituals, and ceremonies.
